newsitem.title: GERMANY: Only one in four Germans want Kohl as chancellor.
newsitem.headline: Only one in four Germans want Kohl as chancellor.

text.p: Only one in four Germans want Helmut Kohl to remain as their chancellor while more than half would prefer Gerhard Schroeder, the Social Democratic premier of Lower Saxony, a survey published on Thursday said.

The Forsa survey of 1,102 Germans, to be broadcast on ARD television's Monitor programme, said 25 percent wanted Kohl as chancellor compared to 52 percent for Schroeder, considered to be a front-running SPD candidate to challenge Kohl in 1998.

The poll also offered an unusual glimpse of voter sentiment by comparing ministers in Kohl's centre-right coalition government with possible "shadow" ministers from the opposition SPD and Greens, which could form the next government.

Finance Minister Theo Waigel received only 30 percent support against 39 percent for his SPD counterpart, Ingrid Matthaeus-Maier. But he would beat SPD chairman Oskar Lafontaine, sometimes mentioned as a possible SPD finance minister, by a score of 38 to 30.
Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel of the Free Democrats would win 55 percent of the vote compared to 25 percent for Joschka Fischer of the Greens.
Defence Minister Volker Ruehe of Kohl's Christian Democrats (CDU) would also fare well, taking 51 percent to 25 percent for Rudolf Scharping of the SPD.
Health Minister Horst Seehofer, like Waigel a member of the Bavarian Christian Social Union (CSU) allied to Kohl's CDU, would lose to Rudolf Dressler of the SPD by a score of 42 to 29.
